title: 108_hr4881
content: The Act may be cited as the "NASA and JPL 50th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act" and includes specifications for the coin. The "NASA and JPL 50th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of $10 gold coins, $5 gold coins, and $1 silver coins in limited quantities to commemorate the anniversary of NASA and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The "NASA and JPL 50th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of $10 gold coins, $5 gold coins, and $1 silver coins in limited quantities to commemorate the anniversary of NASA and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items, with specific requirements for the composition and diameter of the silver coins. SEC. 3. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the achievements of NASA and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Each coin will include the coin's value, the year 2008, and inscriptions such as "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". Additional inscriptions may be added as determined by the Secretary. The $10 coins will feature a design honoring fallen astronauts. $5 coins will have designs representing Moon and Earth missions of NASA. The $1 coins will have specific designs on the obverse side. The $1 coins issued under this Act will honor the achievements of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory on the obverse side and feature 8 different designs representing the planets of the solar system on the reverse side. The reverse of the half dollar coins will bear an image of the universe, selected for realism and scientific accuracy reminiscent of the Golden Age of Coinage in the United States. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected accordingly. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with various entities and reviewed by the Citizens Coin Advisory Committee. Symbolic inclusion of precious metals that have flown in space. Each Federal agency and instrumentality of the United States with space crafts must retrieve precious metals for coin production as determined by the Director of the United States Mint. The metals should be deposited with the Mint. (b) Federal agencies and instrumentality of the United States must segregate and keep records of retrieved precious metals separately. The Director of the US Mint will use these metals for coin production by blending them with other bullion. The precious metals obtained from crafts that flew in space will be used for coin production by blending them with other bullion. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. The Secretary shall make at least 25,000 sets of coins available, each containing coins of each denomination and design required. Only one facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike coins. Issuance may begin on January 1, 2008, and no coins may be minted after December 31, 2008. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act include surcharges: $75 for the $10 coin, $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $3 for the half dollar coin. Surcharges received will be promptly paid to the NASA Family Assistance Fund for financial assistance to families of NASA personnel who die in the line of duty. The Fund is subject to audit requirements. The audit requirements of section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code, pertain to the amounts received under subsection (b).
